“If you lack discipline, open this”
Psychology Thread
 Choose a Goal  Begin by choosing just one goal that you want to focus on to develop your self-discipline.
Remember, starting small is the best way to start developing your self-discipline.
Nutrition, Sleep and Exercise Are Key  If you are trying to improve your self discipline and you’re not getting enough sleep, healthy food and exercise, you’re fighting an uphill battle.
If you do the above, you’ll have more energy and an overall positive attitude.
It’s About the Habit, Not the Outcome  Rather than saying “I want to lose weight” say “I want to walk at least 10,000 steps per day.”
“Losing weight” is something difficult to pin down.
Walking 10,000 steps per day is something concrete that you can track and measure.
Time flies  Take a close look at where you are spending your time and energy.
The average adult spends five hours per day looking at their smartphone.
With this in mind, NOT constantly scrolling through social media on your phone can make a huge difference in your day.
You Don’t Need Permission From Anyone  Building self discipline means that you will need to learn how to find that approval within yourself.
Once we let go of this need for approval from others, we are free to follow our goals and work on what is important to us.
Be Nice to Yourself  Change is hard. New habits are hard.
Our minds are wired for familiarity and if youâ€™re doing something new, part of you is going to be fighting against it.
Donâ€™t allow obstacles to cause you to give up on your bigger vision or goal.
Just one pushup  Do one pushup, once you get started you’ll end up doing more.
It works for self discipline in any area.
Don’t worry if the goal you set for yourself is easy - that’s the point.
The key is to choose something that is so easy that you can’t say no.
Punch the Clock  You will have good days and bad days, but what matters is that you show up.
There will be some mornings where you feel tired and you won’t have your best workout ever.
It’s still incredibly important to follow through and go to the gym anyways.
You live your life on auto pilot because you don’t know what to do with your life.  Get “Live Intentionally” and become;
â€¢ Motivated â€¢ Disciplined â€¢ Your best self â€¢ Self-confident
Get the book here: Live Intentionally: 90 Day Self-Improvement Program (https://lifemathmoney.gumroad.com/l/tough)

Had a DM question asking for advice for a brand new analyst working at a pod shop. Noodled on it, and figured I would share the thoughts broadly in case helpful. I am far from the most tenured and successful pod PM - spent 4 years as a PM at combo of D.E. Shaw (not a pod)â€¦
Citadel/Aptigon and Schonfeld, over which time I hired/employed/trained a dozen or so analysts. (And then threw up two middle fingers and retiredâ€¦more on that later). So Iâ€™m by no means the absolute authority on pods. But here is my advice:
  Youâ€™re job is make your PMâ€™s life easier. Full stop. Donâ€™t forget this. Run through walls for PM. Let PM know this. Donâ€™t whine and complain about your â€œcareer developmentâ€ or comp in your first two years. Donâ€™t do it. That era will come. Be a ride or die, and let PM know it
  Use your â€œgolden three monthsâ€. Life happens fast at pods. It has to - itâ€™s sink or swim. However, you CAN be the naive newbie for 3 months. So ask questions!! Create a running list, ask PM for 10 min a week and ask anything you donâ€™t understand. Donâ€™t pretend like you do!!!
  2 contd) Use more senior analysts on team as resource. But you have 3 months. By month 6 the naive newbie schtick will be old, and you will be expected to contribute. Sell side teach in calls can be helpful. Be a sponge. Be a sponge. Be a sponge.
 learn to communicate. Seasoned pod players have a distinct communication style. Terse. Direct. No BS. Tell me what I need to know and no more. They donâ€™t have time to waste on 15 minute convos about your weekend. This isnâ€™t I-banking. Mimic how Sr analysts speak to PM.
  Zero defect mentality. This isnâ€™t I-banking where you send a deck to associate, get 56 markups and turn the deck 6 more times. Donâ€™t send anything to PM until it has been 5x checked and perfect. Fastest way to ruin reputation is to send sloppy work.
  Study compliance procedures very carefully. Contrary to some beliefs, pod PMs are insanely careful about MNPI and donâ€™t want to touch gray areas. Personal trading, consultant calls and mgmt meetings are focus areas. Make sure you donâ€™t foot fault here. If you make a mistakeâ€¦
  5 contd) â€¦that gets firm involved it will be very bad for you. You are easy to fire. Compliance and the GC are your friends and use them proactively (donâ€™t assume you know the answer). Even if you can own individual stocks I would just own indexes first few years.
 become the â€œtechie, data guyâ€. Learn all the risk model UI, excel pulls, Bloomberg bells and whistles, etc. There is a lot of this and PMs are older and less tech savvy. Become friends with the data science team and become your teams internal data guy. Add value like this.
  FILO. First in, last out. Shouldnâ€™t have to say this, but i do. It matters. Donâ€™t take vacation your first year. Sounds harsh, but your first 12 months isnâ€™t a career, itâ€™s a try out. Treat it that way.
  Find your voice. You donâ€™t want to be the arrogant know it all, but you donâ€™t want be the person who canâ€™t take a stand. Observe, listen more than you speak, contemplate, but when you have an opinion you must voice it. Use data, analogs, and facts to support, not opinion.
  be a culture carrier. Make it about your team, not yourself. Be even keeled in drawdowns. Be yourself, tell jokes, do your best to be likeable. Obsessively identify ways to be helpful. Be a fixture at team happy hours, etc
  know the game you chose, and embrace it. Pod life is fundamentally impermanent. You could make a million+ a year by year 3 or be fired in 3 months. You cannot be too attached for either outcome or you will drive yourself mad. Embrace the uncertainty. Some teams/seats lastâ€¦
  10 contd) â€¦for years. But the pod GPâ€™s are fundamentally PM traders who cut losers and let winers run. Given the leverage, it canâ€™t be any other way. So ride the ride - highs will be euphoric and lows will be depressive. Thats life. In 3-5 years, you will have battle scarsâ€¦
10 contd) â€¦and tons of lessons learned (keep a trading journal), and if you do it right you will turn into a total badass money maker. But itâ€™s a journey, and you wonâ€™t be there day 1. Best luck!
